CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, April 30, 1949, pg. 1, reads: "Doors Shut to King Cole - Pictured above is Hotel Mayfair, Penn Avenue, where King Cole and his wife were allegedly refused accommodations Monday, while two white employes [employees] of the famous musician were given rooms. Manager Fred Armbrust alleges that refusal was 'all a misunderstanding,' but King Cole claims the night clerk 'deliberately and coldly' refused to allow him to register because 'this hotel does not take Negroes.' - Harris Photo."Cutline for image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, National Edition, May 7, 1949, pg. 1, reads: "Nat (King) Cole Sues Hotel - Denied Rooms - Noted Singer Sues Hotel In Pittsburgh - Nat (King) Cole (right, top photo), signs legal papers in his $25,000 damage suit against Mayfair Hotel (bottom photo) in Pittsburgh, Pa., as his wife (center) and attorneys, Paul F. Jones (left) and Thomas E. Barton look on. - Harris Photos."  Portion of accompanying article reads: "Nat (King) Cole filed a $25,000 damage suit against the Hotel Mayfair here last Thursday.  The first civil suit filed in Pittsburgh in forty years grew out of charges that the nationally famous musician and his wife were refused rooms at the hotel April 25, after two white members of the Cole entourage had received accommodations..."Hotel was demolished for Gateway Center.
TitMainTitle: Exterior of Mayfair Hotel and Restaurant, subject of racial discrimination lawsuit by Nat King Cole, Downtown Pittsburgh
